===Etymology 1===
From {{etyl|zhx|ja|sort=おうとう}} {{m|zh|櫻桃}}.

====Pronunciation====
* [[音読み|On'yomi]]
* {{ja-pron|おうとう}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|おうとう|kyu=櫻桃|hhira=あうたう}}

# alternate for {{l|ja|桜|tr=''sakura''}}: a [[cherry]] [[tree]]
# the {{m|ja|西洋実桜|tr=seiyō mizakura}}, the [[wild cherry]], ''[[Prunus avium]]''
# the {{m|ja|英桃|tr=yusura ume}}, the {{vern|downy cherry|pedia=1}}, {{taxlink|Prunus tomentosa|species|noshow=1}}
# {{lb|ja|sort=おうとう|euphemistic}} a [[beautiful]] [[woman]]; a beautiful woman's [[lip]]s

===Etymology 2===
Numerous theories.

Possibly a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=さくらんぼう|桜|tr1=sakura|t1=cherry tree|の|tr2=no|t2=possessive particle|穂|tr3=ho|t3=a bud or fruit towards the end of a long stem}}. The ''no'' [[contract]]s to ''n''. The ''ho'' changes to ''bo'' due to {{rendaku|さくらんぼう}}.

Alternately, a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=さくらんぼう|桜|tr1=sakura|t1=cherry tree|の|tr2=no|t2=possessive particle|坊|tr3=bō|t3=a monk}}, also used as a suffix to indicate affection, also used to allude to the round smooth shape of a monk's shaven head.

Alternately, a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=さくらんぼう|桜|tr1=sakura|t1=cherry tree|桃|tr2=momo|t2=peach; any bulging round fruit}}.
